snippet.title: MIFF review: Low-budget comedy debut Lemon strays into uncomfortable territory
snippet.content:
LEMON ★★ 1/2 Melbourne International Film Festival Hoyts Melbourne Central, August 6, 4.15pm and August 11, 9pm
Quirky comedies come in all flavours. Janicza Bravo's low-budget first feature Lemon is the cruel, abrasive kind, akin to the work of Todd Solondz​ (Happiness) and Alex Ross Perry (Listen Up Philip).Photo: Asha Holmes Publicity Isaac (co-writer Brett Gelman) is a middle-aged actor living in the suburbs, given to naive racism and boasts about his supposed glory days in New York. With his girlfriend (Judy Greer) running out of patience, he finds solace in the mutual admiration society he's formed with his preening protege (Michael Cera). Gradually, it becomes clear that Isaac is not merely geeky but mentally ill and the film is willing to get into some genuinely uncomfortable areas, particularly when he tries to start a fresh relationship with a Jamaican-American woman (Nia Long). Still, it never stops feeling like a strained in-joke, with dialogue made up of relentless non-sequiturs and a cast full of familiar faces from cable TV.
